Award.AwardTitle: Regulation and function of RFRP-3 neurons in the inhibition of mammalian reproduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stress can drastically inhibit fertility and reproductive status, but how this happens in the body and brain is poorly understood. Indeed, although the negative effects of stress on reproduction are well appreciated, the specific signaling factors and neural mechanisms that converge in the brain to inhibit reproduction under stressful conditions remain poorly defined. This proposal will use novel mouse models and neural gene profiling to test how psychosocial stress alters inhibitory neural circuits in the brain in relation to controlling fertility. This proposal will substantially expand our knowledge of how stressors "communicate" with specific parts of the brain that control reproduction. This information will significantly advance the field of reproductive neuroendocrinology. Moreover, given the common theme of stress inhibition on reproduction in many animals, this research will ultimately have broad impact for better understanding brain and hormone functioning of multiple vertebrate species. The research component is complemented and integrated with a comprehensive broader impact plan which includes training and mentoring undergraduate students and post-doctoral scholars, including women and under-represented minorities. The proposal also includes a program aimed at engaging under-represented minority high school students in science research, as well as a new brain research outreach program and internship collaboration with a local high school with students from diverse ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds.

Stress can inhibit fertility and reproductive status, but exactly how this occurs mechanistically is poorly understood. Reproduction is simulated by gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion from the brain. The highly-conserved neuropeptide RFamide-related peptide-3 (RFRP-3), encoded by the Rfrp gene, negatively regulates the reproductive axis by inhibiting GnRH secretion. However, very little is known about the phenotype, regulation, or functional necessity of RFRP-3 neurons. As an inhibitor of GnRH, RFRP-3 is poised to relay inhibitory stress signals to the reproductive axis, but this requires testing. This proposal will utilize new transgenic RFRP-3 mouse models (the first of their kind), coupled with cutting-edge molecular tools, to functionally test the involvement and necessity of RFRP-3 neurons in mediating the negative effects of stress on reproductive status, as well as identify novel brain genes that are activated under stressful and non-stressful conditions. This study will therefore provide fresh insight into the physiological regulation and functional roles of RFRP-3 neurons and other brain circuitry in the modulation of reproductive status during stress, and will empirically probe RFRP-3 regulation and function in new ways that have not been possible with former histological and pharmacological methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the 4-year grant period, we performed multiple activities, both research and outreach, summarized briefly below.

Intellectual Merit:

The brain regulates reproduction via the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which in turn stimulates luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion from the pituitary. However, the factors that regulate GnRH secretion under different conditions are still poorly defined. RFamide-related peptide-3 (RFRP-3) is a neuropeptide in the hypothalamus that negatively regulates the reproductive axis by inhibiting GnRH secretion, whereas kisspeptin is a neuropeptide that stimulates GnRH. While more is known about kisspeptin neurons, little is known about RFRP-3 neurons, which is poised to relay inhibitory regulatory signals, such as stress, to the reproductive axis. Indeed, stress can inhibit reproductive function, but how this occurs is poorly understood. This project aimed to better understand how stress system interacts with key reproductive neural systems, like kisspeptin and RFRP-3 cells.

The first major research outcome provided new insight into the negative effects of psychosocial stress on reproductive neuroendocrine activity. We investigated the impact of short-term (90 minutes) psychosocial stress on the secretion of LH pulses and activation status of kisspeptin and RFRP-3 neurons in female mice. We found that acute psychosocial stress induced a rapid and very robust suppression of pulsatile LH secretion. Moreover, psychosocial stress caused a potent decrease in kisspeptin neuron activation, whereas RFRP-3 neurons were more activated during stress. These findings suggest that stress causes increases in RFRP-3 neuronal activation, which provide increased inhibition onto the reproductive axis. Simultaneously, stress also lower kisspeptin activation, which reduces stimulation onto the reproductive axis.

A second major research outcome focused on possible sex differences in how the brain responds to psychosocial stress. Given reported sex differences in sensitivity to stress, we examined whether acute stress alters in vivo LH secretion and reproductive neural populations in males as in females. We found that LH pulses in male mice are significantly suppressed by acute restraint stress, with suppression observed very rapidly (12 minutes) after stress exposure, similar to that seen in females. Unlike females, males showed no changes in kisspeptin neural activation during early stages of stress exposure, suggesting an important sex difference in how stress may signal in the brain. In contrast, RFRP-3 neuron activation was increased in males after stress initiation, as in females. Thus during stress, decreased LH secretion may reflect increased RFRP-3 neuronal activation in males whereas females rely on changes to both kisspeptin and RFRP-3 systems.

A third major research outcome addressed the role of the adrenal stress hormone corticosterone (CORT). In animals, acute psychosocial stress strongly decreases LH secretion, but how this occurs is unknown. We tested the possibility that CORT may be mediating the decrease in LH induced by stress. We found that a one-time CORT injection moderately and temporarily suppresses LH pulses, suggesting some neuroendocrine effects of psychosocial stress are likely due to CORT action but other factors are also likely involved. A related research outcome focused on whether CORT disrupt ovarian cyclicity in females by interfering with the preovulatory sequence of endocrine events necessary for the LH surge. We showed that long-term CORT exposure arrested cyclicity in female mice and completely blocked the LH surge which induces ovulation. We also learned that chronic CORT suppressed the synthesis of kisspeptin and the activation of kisspeptin cells, providing novel information of how stress system interacts with the reproductive system.

Collectively, this research provided a better understanding of how stress and stress hormones inhibit reproductive function by regulating critical reproductive circuits in the brain, in particular, RFRP-3 and kisspeptin neural circuits. Given the presence of both kisspeptin and RFRP-3 in many species, and common effects of stress in vertebrates, these findings shed new light on reproductive control and stress biology with relevance for multiple animal species.

Broader Impact

Regarding educational activities, Dr. Kauffman directly mentored numerous lab members in both technical skills and intellectual skills (critical thinking), including underrepresented minorities and women. This included 9 women and 3 men, and 5 minority trainees. Dr. Kauffman also served as course Director in a University graduate course on neuroendocrinology (NEU222). For outreach activities, Dr. Kauffman and Dr. Breen participated in multiple programs aimed at educating high school students about brain science and research, and exposing minority and under-represented high school students directly to hands-on research experiences. These latter experiences included lectures at local high schools, hands-on lab visits for high school juniors, intensive lab internships for high school students, and high school student mentorship via the University's MAP program. One of these programs was "highlighted" in a national news story in Endocrine News in 2018. Via these Broader Impact actions, we inspired under-represented minority high school students to stay in school, apply to college, consider becoming involved in science research, and succeed in their science education, and ultimately consider STEM fields for their careers.
